Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 12:45PM mom2daughters wrote: Hi harley, did you lose all your eye brows as well.  When do they start growing back.  Just trying to plan for the inevitable I guess.  thanks................... K
Posts.Title: Taxotere and Cytoxan - hair loss mom2daughters Harley44

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 06:44AM mom2daughters wrote: Hi Hummer, I too was just dx (on 1/2 with IDC stage IIIA).  Don't know much else yet.    It feels very surreal. My husband and I had a great weekend reading the Dr. Loves Breast Book and oddly enough, Breast Cancer for Dummies.  We both wrote alot of questions down and I just got off the phone with my surgeon and she answered them all.  I met with a surgeon two days after my mammo/ultra sound was done.  I absolutely love her and her office staff.  My mast. is scheduled for 1/14.  They are doing the SNB right then also.  She'll scoot over (her words) to path with them and if they are pos, take some more, if not, leave those buggers in.  But the ta-ta is leaving.  Just the left, (so the left will leave as my daughter so lovingly has said).  I haven't cried yet. I'm sure it will come.  Just trying to get everything ready.  I'm in my early 40's with two teenage daughters who are so helpful.  My husband has been great, I only wish his company was more understanding about taking time off.  We're working on that now.  Here's a hug for you and I know its scary.  I have known now for 5 days and it still hasn't set in.  Love to you and your family - kim
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed hummer Jen44

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 05:01PM mom2daughters wrote: Hi all - Jenny what does TAC mean.  I know what you all mean about kids, they do get you through this.  My girls are wonderful and I don't think I could get through this without them.  Always taking care of me, I'm getting spoiled! K
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed hummer Jen44

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 10:32PM mom2daughters wrote: How about wigs, anyone have a problem traveling while wearing one.  Is it better to travel with a scarf or hat?
Posts.Title: hats and wigs lisa49 mom2daughters

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2008 09:10PM mom2daughters wrote: Thanks Barbara - your words were much needed today.  Suddenly feeling very overwhelmed and very alone.  I think the initial shock wore off.  Its been 4 days since I found out, but still haven't cried.  Just hope I'm not in Stop N'Shop or Walmart and let loose.   My mind is starting to go ditzy.  I am second guessing everything and can't seem to remember anything that the doctor said on Wednesday.  I'm making a list of questions for her and/or her office.  I am still trying to figure out what to do the first night.  Do you need someone with you the first day as well.  My husband probably can't take off the two days.  He's in a new job and they aren't very understaning right now. I would like him with me with we go to the onc. on 2/1, so he needs to take that day off.  I will get someone to drive me for my post-op, I'm ok there, but the first night is still the question. I'm still up in the air about my mother-in-law.  I do love her, but since I told her, she has called 3 times a day, which I know is great because she cares, but she is telling me to stop reading about "it", stop researching "it", just wait and see what happens, your looking ahead too much...  Its kind of driving me crazy.  For my sake I need to take control of this and know what can happen before it happens so I can ask the surgeon. I'm sure she means well, and I'm happy she feels so comfortable with me telling me this, but I don't know.  Maybe I'm just tired finally, and everything is starting to boil up.  Thanks for listening - Kim XO
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 09:00AM mom2daughters wrote: Hi Barb, thank you for your kind words.  I FINALLY slept well last night and I have been praying for some calm.  I feel much better this morning and I had a great surprize this morning -- everyone in my house got up on their own, dog feed and walked,  and out on time, so that is one problem I don't have to worry about next week. I had a nice talk with my husband and we worked out what will work best for us the first few days.  He is taking off the first two days then his mother will come during the day to help after that for a few days.  I have a list of questions for the surgeon and have things here at home ready.  I already had a feeling a recliner would work best.  I had so many biopsies done before the dx and I remember how more comfortable it was to sleep semi-reclined than flat.  (I'm a roller).  Great idea on getting the bathroom ready for sponge bath.  My one daughter was critically ill a few years back and when she finally came home from the hospital she was unable to walk on her own, so I have all those things somewhere.  I have a craft apron, kind of like the carpenter one, that has pockets on it.  I use it in class all the time, so I have that for the drains.  My good friend lives a few minutes away and she is a home health nurse, so if we run into a problem with drains, she said she will pop over right away.  And the acutally I got a call from my husbands mom last night, asking if we need anything and out of the blue she apologiezed if she was comign on strong or pestering.  She said she felt bad I didn't have a mom to talk to about it, but realized that I do have a great family with brothers and sisters, great friends and co-workers and that she might be smothering me.  (God is good and answers our prayers)  So - all worked out and def. my strong faith has helped.  I am just such a planner, and an A type, that maybe this is His way of telling me, let you and let people help for once.   (Plus I have you and all these great women on the board to help me) - thansk for everything - K
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 07:02AM mom2daughters wrote: WOW Barbara, you are amazing.  Its still not sinking in.  I was just dx on 1/2 with IDC, stage IIIA, and will have my mastecomy on 1/14.  I am keeping busy preparing and reading this wonderful site.  After reading your comments I feel so much better.  I am getting a radical mastecomy in my left breast and I live in NJ and my surgery is done on an outpatient.  The only thing I worry about is the first night and trying to get everyone up for school/work the next day.  I have teenagers and a husband who have slept through a fire alarm once and a few weeks ago, the wind set off our house alarm and no one but me heard it.  My own mom died at 54 of ovarian, so she isn't around to help, but my husbands mom is close by.  My father-in-law passed away a  few months ago from a sudden stroke and she said she she needs something to do to keep her busy.  So I might try and plan something out with her. Of well, thanks for everything.  Any other tips/prep for surgery and especially after care you can think of.  I don't know what state of mind I'll be in when they go over discharge instructions, that's the only thing I don't like about same day surgery for mastecomy, but I'll be happy to be home with my husband/kids and dog  Thanks for all your help - K
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 11:17AM mom2daughters wrote: Annie and Otter, you two crack me up - I never laughed so hard, thought my fake boobie would pop out........   Annie, I am with you there, I sat in my car for ten minutes yesterday.  I completely forgot how to turn the blinker off.  I kept putting the wiper on.  My husband had to come out and help.  He gave me the benefit of the doubt, though, He said the steering wheel was turned a bit and was covering the blinker.God I love that man. I also found the Biotine and some of the Tom products have helped.  So far mouth has been OK, just very dry.   Hugs - Kim

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 12:40PM mom2daughters wrote: quick question for all you January warriors - I am still waiting for my oncotype test to come back but was wondering what is the time frame from when you went to the oncologist office to discuss treatment to the actual start date.  Do you have any further tests done, or just go.  I had my mastecomy 1/14 and know I have to start moving on treatment.  Is there a time frame that you need to follow as far as surgery dates/treatment, etc.  Thanks  Sorry for the questions, a whole lot of things whirling through my head.

Dana - loved your prayer for the day, needed that - hugs K

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 12:16PM mom2daughters wrote: Thanks to all for information about time-frame from surgery to treatment.  Good to know I can still "shop" and dont' have to rush and buy anything.  I will keep you all in my prayers.  You are all so positive and uplifting.  I certainly enjoy coming over to this group/ topic, you seem to really care about eachother, and I really appreciate all the posts about how your treatments went and advice.  hugs-K
Posts.Title: Jan 2008--Ain't it Great? Determined1 Diana63

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 09:13AM - edited Feb 21, 2008 09:15AM by mom2daughters Hi I've been reading everyones posts and I am waiting to see if I will be joining your Feb. group, will hopefully find out my treatment plan on Monday.  I appreciate everyones posts and comments.  It makes it all easier to understand Nolana & Gail- good luck today, please post when you are able to, I will be thinking of you both.  Grannie/Rose- hope you have an easy time with your port.   Bee-Good luck also today too, I'll keep you in my thoughts. Did you have to have anything done before you start, Nuelasta, anything for the nausea, steriods, etc. Bridget - Hang in there.  believe me I know the waiting to start treatment is driving me crazy.   I just want to get this show on the road.  The only thing that I makes me feel better is knowing my body is healing and will be stronger to fight the chemo Thanks to all for posting your experiences and suggestions, makes sense of all this craziness. - Hugs K
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 11:28AM - edited Feb 26, 2008 11:33AM by mom2daughters Well its official I start Chemo on Thursday 2/28. What an up and down ride its been.  But I love my new onc. and am glad to finally get the show on the road.  I will be having 4 rounds of TC,and  the day after each treatment I will be having the Neulasta shots,  after all 4 treatments  I'll start Tamoxifen and then we'll deal with my ovaries.  I have a PET scan set up also.  Just trying to get insurance approval.  I went last week to meet with the first onc I met with (which was right after my surgery)  to go over the oncotype test, I was told I was really low (score of 10) and no chemo.  I got a call late in the day from the nurse, they gave me the wrong score! --- accidently someone elses report with a simiar name was put in my file, and mine in theirs, luckily they finally noticed the mix-up during the other women's appoint.  I never even looked up at the name on top, I just kept focusing on the numbers and chart -GRRRRR. --- Supsposedly, they got alot of reports back from genomic the same day and mis-filed mine, oh well.  I could be angry for all the confusion, but I am glad I am not going to that office again.  It didn't feel right from day one, I never felt comfortable there.  I absolutely love my new dr, the facility and staff, exactly what I wanted in a dr. Wish me luck and any, any advise, please let me know.  I have been reading over some of the old posts to update myself.  Thanks in advance -  I am sure I'll be posting again (and again, and again) before Thursday AM - hugs K
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 10:52AM mom2daughters wrote: Hi  - just a quick question for all you pros - I have developed a small rash on my face. Its just on one cheek.  Other than dry skin on my arms, I don't have it anywhere else.  Have any of you had something similiar, and if so, what did you use.  I have had 2 tx of T/C, and have my next in a week.  Thanks - Kim
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 02:39PM mom2daughters wrote: Hi everyone.  Wow, that was interesting yesterday.  First treatment was a breeze, taxotore and cytoxan.  I went for my neulasta shot today and so far so good.  Didn't have to take any thing other than an advil yesterday, slight headace and a dry mouth.  Steriods still kicking in so not tired.  Had a nice lunch with my husband after treatment. Treatment took much longer than I thought.  They ran the drips slow so I wouldn't have any problems and explained what each was before they changed the bags.  Very nice place and I love my new doctor.  They passed out cake, and ice cream adn were bringing in lunch for the afternoon people.  I was sorry to leave.  They told me to take some advil for the bone pain from the neulasta adn I filled the perscription for Zofran, but haven't had to use it yet.  Keeping fingers crossed.  I go back next week for blood and hope to have the PET/CT scan scheduled.  Thanks for your good wishes and all your suggestions.  They really came in handy.  I as a pro.  Thanks - Hugs Kim
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 12:58PM mom2daughters wrote: Wow, you have all been busy.  had to go back a page to see how everyone was doing.  Bridget -  you are in my prayers.  Aurora, you make me hungry. Patricia, you said it right, "all of chemo has been weird".  I have noticed more little things going on than I have in my lifetime.     Things have been ok, knock on wood.  Its been 5 days out of first treatment and so far so good.  I did have some cramping and lower back pain on Sat and sun, but think that might be the neualsta shot.  I have been trying to keep busy.  Having trouble sleeping, racing thoughts.  Tonight I might try a "Simply Sleep" from tylenol. Period finally over, hurray!!  Thought I would bleed out.  Have my post op. visit tomorrow with Surgeon to check on mastec.  Scars look good, no pain, will be getting my perscription for my fake "boobie", so I'll shop for wig and boob same time, YIKES.  Haven't had much of an appetite., hard to get my hunger up, drinking lots.  Well, hugs to all - Kim
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 09:47PM mom2daughters wrote: Hi you February pros, what would  I do without you. Rose, I too had to lay down this afternoon, first time I did that in a while.  This whole thing is starting to wear me down. S/E wise I am doing well, but mentally, for some reason, last night and today were bad.   Well the hair is a coming out.  I do know its thick, but my sister said now it looks like her thin hair (trying to make me feel better).  Donna, I'm in NJ too.  I have a dr. appoint in the am also, but just a visit.  Wow, wicked winds lately, yikes.  Still have those trees laying around the yard from Saturdays storm. My daughters and I worked out our trip to Boston.  We are excited to do some planning and get away from all this.  I think it will do us good.   Thanks to all for your support and answering my zillion questions.    Be well, hugs, Kim

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 11:24PM mom2daughters wrote: So far so good, its only been 3 days out from treatment 1, but just some pretty intense cramp like feeling. But I do have my period, yet again, and its very heavy.  Some lower back pain, but otherwise, was able to have a good day, baked a cake with my daughter, and drove my other to SAT test, lunch after and then cleaned, vacuum almost did me in, but felt good to keep busy, and not think too much about how I felt.  Is the cramping/lower back normal.  I am on TC and had my neulasta yesterday.  Thanks - hugs to all, sleep tight - Kim
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 11:30AM - edited Feb 27, 2008 11:33AM by mom2daughters Hi all - Hope everyone is doing well.  Tomorrow morning is the day - I start on T/C.  Any last minute tips appreciatad.  Woke up with a wicked headache, hoping it doesn't change into a full-blown migraine.  Took advil and put a cooling cloth on my head.  I am sure it is stress. Laurel - is your 2nd treatment today - hope it went well.  I'm curious about the coffee too, gotta have my tea or coffee.   Nolana -how are you feeling today.I called the Dr. yesterday and I will not be taking steriods before my TC, only during, not sure after will find out tomorrow.  Its so interesting that each dr. has their own way of doing things.  I am only getting 4 treatments, so that might be why................ Patricia - YIKES on the PET scan.  I have to have mine scheduled still.  Insurance approved it, now I have to wait for the confirmation number.  What a great gift from your friend - I love the boxing gloves!  I hope the friend who is waiting for her score to come back has good news.  She is lucky to have you to help guide her and give her advice.  My score, when I finally got the right one-grrrr- was 22. Its a nerve racking wait. I hope hers comes back quickly.  I think poor Otter is still waiting, not sure. Krista good luck with your second treatment tomorrow.  I'll be thinking of you, as I get my first hook-up going. Bridget, I loved the feeling of freedom I had when my drains were out after my mastecomy.  I have yet to find a "boobie" I like, so around the house, I'm just hanging easy.  Have to go to the "Boobie" store still to find a fitter who can help me.  I have been wearing a cami with a support in it when I go out and wear lots of layers so no one can notice too much.      Well, I hope I did not forget anyone, I think I might have, but never on purpose.  I am forgetting everything lately, I forgot my poor daughter at school yesterday, Thank goodness for cell phones.  Hugs - K
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 08:51AM mom2daughters wrote: Hi everyone - Question for your pros - How are/did you feel around your third treatment.  Were you able to do some traveling if you had to.  Reason I am asking ...........in April my kids are off and we planned a 4 day college visit trip to Boston. It would just be the three of us, myself and two daughters and we would fly up from NJ.  I mentioned it to the dr., he said it would be OK, just watch out for germs.  It would be my "good" week (if you can call it that). I would be having my 4th Chemo the week after we are back.  Any thoughts.........I am having really minimual s/e, only been 10 days out of my first treatment, but overall I've been really lucky.  Another qeustion  - hair.  I have super thick hair.  It is just now starting to thin alittle.  Did everyone lose their hair, or just go super, super thin.  It was 20 years ago, but my mom had Chemo for ovarian cancer and went for about 10 tx, she never lost hers completely, just really thinned out so she cut it into a short pixie cut.  I don't remember what her "cocktail" was though, maybe A/C.  I really don't care about losing it, just want to have an idea of what to expect, can't take the planner out of me.  This week is my PET/CT scan, looking forward to getting that over with.  I've been reading and catching up with all your posts.  You all make me smile.  Running in to say hi to work today, so I'm going to get ready - be well - Kim
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Feb 2008? nowwhat cancerviking

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 10:56AM mom2daughters wrote: Hi everyone - well thanks to you fab feb. ladies, I had another great treatment, 2 down, 2 to go.  Your advice, knowledge, love and support help me though each one. The only complaint I had yesterday is I couldn't sleep, I know how important it is to rest, but those darn steriods had me up till 2 in the morning.  Had to get up early at 6:00 went for my shot and then did some food shopping for Easter.  We are all set. Yesterday was a good day overall, my 17 year old received two acceptances from colleges, and my treatment went well.  Hopefully the s/e will be mini. like last time. Hope everyone's day is filled with joy, peace and good friends/family.  Be well everyone - Kim
